snippet: A move to curb mandatory minimum sentences and a ruling that stop-and-frisk practices in New York were unconstitutional represented a swing away from the tough-on-crime policies of a generation ago.
abstract: News analysis; move to curb mandatory minimum sentence laws and ruling that stop-and-frisk practices in New York are unconstitutional are signals that pendulum has swung away from tough-on-crime policies; critics have long contended that draconian mandatory minimum sentence laws for low-level drug offenses, as well as stop-and-frisk police policies that target higher-crime and minority neighborhoods, have disproportionate impact on minorities; policies have been denounced as discriminatory and responsible for surge in prison population.

byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and ERICA GOODE
byline.contributor: Charlies Savage reported from Washington, and Erica Goode from New York.

lead_paragraph: A move to curb mandatory minimum sentences and a ruling that stop-and-frisk practices in New York were unconstitutional represented a swing away from the tough-on-crime policies of a generation ago.

headline.main: Two Powerful Signals of a Major Shift on Crime
